hints_html:
The substitution

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle w = v^{-1/2}\end{aligned}\]

will simplify matters.

After the substitution you will recover a differential equation that you are familiar with.
hints_latex:
After the substitution you will recover a differential equation that you
are familiar with.
hints_raw:
The substitution 
:<math> \displaystyle w = v^{-1/2}</math>
will simplify matters.
After the substitution you will recover a differential equation that you are familiar with.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
As the exam hint suggests, we make the substitution \(w = v^{-1/2}\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} w' = -\frac{1}{2} v^{-3/2} v'.\end{aligned}\]

Under this substitution, \(t^2 w' + 2tw - w^3 = 0\) becomes

\[\begin{aligned} t^2 (-\frac{1}{2} v^{-3/2} v') + 2t v^{-1/2} - v^{-3/2} &= 0 \\ v' - \frac{4}{t} v + \frac{2}{t^2} &= 0 \end{aligned}\]

where we multiplied the equation by \(-2 \frac{v^{3/2}}{t^2}.\)

This is now the same ODE as in part (a), so the solution is that \(v = \frac{2}{5t} + Ct^4\). Hence we have

\[\begin{aligned} w = \left( \frac{2}{5t} + Ct^4\right)^{-1/2}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
As the exam hint suggests, we make the substitution <math>w = v^{-1/2}</math> so that 

:<math>w' = -\frac{1}{2} v^{-3/2} v'</math>.

Under this substitution,  <math>t^2 w' + 2tw - w^3 = 0</math> becomes

<math> \begin{align} t^2 (-\frac{1}{2} v^{-3/2} v') + 2t v^{-1/2} - v^{-3/2} &= 0 \\
v' - \frac{4}{t} v + \frac{2}{t^2} &= 0 \end{align} </math> 

where we multiplied the equation by <math>-2 \frac{v^{3/2}}{t^2}.</math>

This is now the same ODE as in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH215/December_2011/Question_01_(a)|part (a)]], so the solution is that <math>v = \frac{2}{5t} + Ct^4</math>. Hence we have

:<math>w = \left( \frac{2}{5t} + Ct^4\right)^{-1/2}</math>.
statement_html:
Solve the following nonlinear ODE:

\[\begin{aligned} t^2 w' + 2tw - w^3 = 0, \quad t > 0.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Solve the following nonlinear ODE:

:<math>
t^2 w' + 2tw - w^3 = 0, \quad t > 0.
</math>
